title: Question 8

children: A 72-year-old man is evaluated for a fever. He was hospitalized 3 days ago for lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
On physical examination, temperature is 38.4 °C (101.1 °F); other vital signs are normal. An inflamed peripheral venous catheter site is discovered. The remainder of the examination is normal.
The venous catheter is removed, blood cultures are obtained, and empiric vancomycin is initiated.
Initial blood cultures grow methicillin-sensitive
Staphylococcus aureus
at 48 hours; repeat cultures are pending. The patient is afebrile.
No valvular vegetations are seen on a transthoracic echocardiogram.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
All patients with
Staphylococcus aureus
bacteremia should undergo echocardiography.
Transesophageal echocardiography may not be necessary after a negative transthoracic echocardiography in some patients with uncomplicated
Staphylococcus aureus
bacteremia at low risk for endocarditis.
The most appropriate management is switching to cefazolin (
Option C

). Following the discovery of an infected peripheral venous catheter site in a febrile patient, appropriate actions include removing the line, obtaining blood cultures, and starting empiric vancomycin therapy to cover the possibility of hospital-acquired methicillin-resistant
Staphylococcus aureus
(MRSA) infection. When the blood cultures identify methicillin-sensitive
S. aureus

(MSSA), antibiotic treatment should be de-escalated. Bacteremia caused by MSSA should be treated intravenously with a penicillinase-resistant semisynthetic penicillin (such as oxacillin) or first-generation cephalosporin (such as cefazolin) at maximal doses. Vancomycin (
Option B

) should be avoided in patients with MSSA who are not allergic to β-lactam antibiotics; vancomycin is associated with higher rates of relapse and microbiologic failure in the treatment of MSSA bacteremia.
Combination antimicrobial therapy (such as vancomycin and rifampin) (
Option A
) for the treatment of
S. aureus

bacteremia has not been shown to improve clinical outcomes and should not be used. Furthermore, this patient's antibiotic regimen should be de-escalated to a β-lactam antibiotic based on blood culture results.
All patients with
S. aureus
bacteremia should undergo echocardiography. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is usually performed first; if a vegetation is identified on TTE, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) (
Option D
) may not be needed. However, if no vegetation is seen on TTE, TEE should be considered. TEE may not be necessary after a negative TTE in some patients with uncomplicated
S. aureus

bacteremia, including in health care–acquired bacteremia, when repeat blood cultures within 96 hours of the first positive culture are negative; if the patient is not undergoing hemodialysis; when no permanent intracardiac prosthetic devices are present (e.g., mechanical cardiac valves); when no signs of endocarditis or secondary foci of infection are present; if fever resolves within 72 hours of the first positive blood culture; and when the focus of infection is promptly removed. This patient may meet the criteria for uncomplicated
S. aureus
bacteremia after repeat blood culture results are known. If the blood cultures are persistently positive, further investigation is warranted to determine the source, and TEE should be pursued.

references: Barton T, Moir S, Rehmani H, et al. Low rates of endocarditis in healthcare-associated Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia suggest that echocardiography might not always be required. Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2016;35:49-55.
